text: Polymerase Chain Reaction - PCR HAEM2001 Biomedical Engineering - 2022 Dr Gavin Owen •HIV Pathogenesis Research Unit, Molecular Medicine and Haematology •Gavin.Owen@wits.ac.za | 7Q12 Objectives •At the end of this lecture you should be able to: –Describe the process of PCR •Calculate copy number •Analyse a PCR gel –Describe reverse transcription –List applications of PCR PCR •Polymerase Chain Reaction •Developed by Kary Mullis –Awarded Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1993 •Replicates DNA without using a living organism •PCR is used to amplify a short, well-defined part of a DNA strand –single gene or part of a gene Principle of PCR PCR is divided into 3 steps (differentiated by temp): 1. Denaturation (95°C): The double stranded DNA “melts”open by disrupting the hydrogen bonds between complementary bases to form single stranded DNA 2. Annealing/Hybridisation (~55°C): Primer anneals to the single stranded DNA 3. Extension/Elongation (72°C): Polymerase adds deoxynucleoside triphosphates in a template-dependent fashion Steps are repeated (cycled) 30-50 times –“thermocycling” PCR automation •Most enzymes denature at high temperatures –Thus after each cycle new enzyme must be added – causes many issues! •Thermostable DNA polymerases –isolated from bacteria that grow in thermal vents on the ocean floor or in hot springs –Taq Polymerase from Thermus aquaticus can withstand 95°C –enzyme activity at ~72°C = 2000 - 4000 nt/min PCR mechanism PCR contains: 1. template DNA 2. polymerase 3. deoxynucleoside triphosphates (dNTPs) 4. TWO synthetic DNA primers (Fwd + Rev, 18-20 nt) PCR mechanism Cycle 1: Denaturation at 95C • Heating to 95C disrupts hydrogen bonding between complementary bases causing the two strands to “melt”apart PCR mechanism Cycle 1: Annealing at ~55C • Primers hybridise to complementary sequences on template • Each primer is sequence specific (20 nucleotide primer = 420 possible combinations) PCR mechanism Cycle 1: Extension at 72C •DNA polymerase extends primers by adding dNTPs in a 5ʹ→3ʹdirection •1st round extension continues until 2 dsDNA sequences are produced PCR mechanism Cycle 1: Extension at 72C PCR mechanism Cycle 2: PCR mechanism Cycle 2: Denaturation at 95C PCR mechanism Cycle 2: Annealing at ~55C PCR mechanism Cycle 2: Extension at 72C PCR mechanism Cycle 2: Extension at 72CPCR = Exponential amplificationPCR = Exponential amplification 𝒚 =𝒂×𝟐𝒙 𝒚 =𝑐𝑜𝑝𝑦𝑛𝑢𝑚𝑏𝑒𝑟 𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑑𝑢𝑐𝑒𝑑 𝒂=𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑡𝑖𝑛𝑔𝑐𝑜𝑝𝑦𝑛𝑢𝑚𝑏𝑒𝑟 𝒙 =𝑐𝑦𝑐𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑢𝑚𝑏𝑒𝑟 •Assuming you start off with a single molecule of a gene you are interested in, how many copies would you have after 30 cycles? Fwd primer (1000-1019) + Rev primer (2440-2449) 1 2 3 RT-PCR •RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription-PCR) –Based on PCR technique •RNA converted to a complementary DNA (cDNA) sequence •cDNA used as template during the PCR Reverse Transcriptase •Reverse Transcriptase catalyzes reverse transcription –Transcription: RNA from DNA template –Reverse transcription: .DNA from RNA template •RT = RNA-dependent DNA polymerase –Uses RNA sequence to produce cDNA –DNA polymerase → requires a primer •RNaseH activity –Specifically recognises an RNA:DNA hybrid and degrades RNA RT-PCRApplications of PCR? •The most versatile molecular tool to date! •Many important applications of PCR –detection of hereditary diseases –diagnosis of infectious diseases –identification of genetic fingerprints (paternity testing, forensic testing) –cloning of genes –quantitation –sequencing
